comment_0:
the song is self-explanatory it's prolly about an English guy who visits Paris and falls in love w/this sweet French girl he meets there but she knows no English and he only knows one phrase in French "Michelle ma belle, 
Sont les Mots qui vont trÃ©s bien ensemble 
TrÃ©s bien ensemble." so he pleads his love to her through this song...
comment_1: I agree with the person who wrote that the lyric is likely just about an English guy, perhaps Paul himself while touring France, who is infatuated with a lovely French girl. The lyric mostly states very primal emotions about desire because anything more complicated is not possible due to the language barrier. The honesty is in that, despite the language barrier, there is really nothing more that could be said anyway. The cleverness is in using the French language, which not only sounds romantic to the English-speakers, but also uses the language barrier as a metaphor for what cannot be expressed through words about feelings, in any language. Using minor chords where he does also emphasizes the angst about wanting to say more than words allow. It's an amazing song in that, though the lyric is not sad, it produces an ambivalence of emotion, combining joy and melancholy. A rich palette in such a deceptively simple song. Between '66 and '67 Paul was at his peak that few writers can match. In my opinion, Paul wrote the 2nd and 3rd best American songs ever in Yesterday and Eleanor Rigby (the best being Mancini's and Merecer's Moon River).
comment_2: I always thought it was "sont les MOTS qui vont tres bien ensemble".. as in.. these are the words that go together well... Actually, I'm pretty sure I'm right..

comment_5:
Well, I'm French, and I agree with what you said : the french part is the exact translation of the english part!!! No need to translate it in english, then, it is already done...
Well, this song is very appreciated by French people, of course, it is nice to hear the Beatles singing in our language!
In addition, his english accent is sooooo cute...
Actually, when hearing "Michelle, ma belle, sont des mots qui vont trÃ¨s bien ensemble, trÃ¨s bien ensemble", it is just what one says to seduce a woman : waw, your name is beautiful, and it goes well with "ma belle"! One could think he just wants make her feel flattered, but he sounds so depressed when singing that, that it is obvious that he is just sad and wants to stay with her, that's all.
comment_6:
Well, none of you even got close.  I wonder how long they will allow my response to remain. We will see. 

Michelle Levallier was born April 5 1960 to Monique Levallier, a French make-up artist living in London, and J. Paul McCartney.  A young, broke and irresponsible Paul had several illegitimate children for which he did not acknowledge nor take responsibility .  When told of the pregnancy, Paul broke off the relationship. Devastated,  Monique moved back to Paris and had Michelle.  Upon Michele's 5th  birthday, Monique sent Paul an extremely  adorable photo of his daughter and told him that Michelle wanted to meet her father.  Paul was very moved by the image of his daughter. However, in 1965 he was in a serious relationship with Jane Asher and he was in the middle of BeatleMania.  Despite his best intentions, he never seemed to find time to go visit his daughter.  He must have felt shame for neglecting his responsibilities. At the same time based upon the song lyrics demonstrated his curiosity for the unconditional love that a father has for his daughter, even though they never met.  So, this song was written as a letter of introduction to his young, French speaking daughter  trying to assure her that although he never met her, that he loves her, that there are valid reasons why he is being a selfish prick and that he will find a way to make time to come see her.  I don't believe that ever happened.  Michelle eventually switched her surname to McCartney, became a bass musician and still lives in Los Angeles.
comment_8: The French chorus means the exact same thing as the English one: Michelle, ma belle (literally, "my beautiful", it's a term of endearnment)/these are words that go together well.
comment_9:
Sont les mots qui vont tres bien ensemble

Sont: conjugation of the verb etre(to be)
Les Mots: The words
Qui: who, or that
vont: conjugation of the verb aller(to go)
Tres: Very
Bien: good or well
Ensemble: together.

Sont les mots qui vont tres bien ensemble means These are words that go together well.

Je peu parle francais, j'etais dans immersion dans ecole.

comment_27:
I love this song. . . I love the Beatles. . .

I hate that I didn't grow up during the Beatles era.


This song is special to me, because my name is Michelle. In fact, I was named after this song. My parents were inspired by the Beatles and intriqued by this song.

I think this song is beautiful, because the man uses the only words he knows in French, the language of his love, to express how he feels about this woman. It's adorable.

"Michelle, my beautiful. These are words that go together well, go together well."

Furthermore, the instrumental is soft and mellow. It perfectly accompanies the lyrics.

"I love you, I love you, I love you. That's all I want to say."

He repeats this simple phrase with such emotion. It's as if he's so in love, he says it over and over again just so everyone knows his feelings towards this woman.

I think this song is more of a romantic song in which the man is expressing his love towards a woman as oppose to its interpretation as a breakup song. It doesn't seem as if "Michelle" is denying him, but rather has difficulty understanding him, because the two speak different languages.

"I think you know by now."

Even though they come from different cultures, he believes that she truly does undestand his love for her. You can express love in other ways than through words.
comment_28:

Sean Penn said that John Lennon added the lyrics "I love you, I love you, I love you. " Without those words, the song will have no meaning.

Hence the great Lennon/McCartney composition. :)

pJ ;P

PS: It's really "these are words that go together well."

comment_37:
The thing that makes The Beatles special to everyone (Me being no exception) is the way they seem to be singing for you, and just you. My mum introduced me to the beatles when I was very young, but I've still not heard Every Song yet. Well, recently, I have fallen madly in love with a beautiful girl named Michele, and after glumly searching through different beatles tracks trying to find some advice hidden inside the lyrics I found this song. Well you can imagine how I felt, and this is the powerful effect that The Beatles have on people. For me, this song gives me the same funny feeling at the pit of my stomach that I get when I'm with Michele, so I listen to it when I'm thinking of her.
Oh, and for the record, she knows how I feel now and she says she feels the same way about me, only there are some complications, but...I'm working on it ;)

comment_45: Actually its not about being in love with a french girl. paul wrote the song and wanted to add something french to it, becasue back their youger days when john took paul to his art school parties back in liverpool evrone thought paul was french coz he used to sit in the corner dressed french looking clothing smoking a fag (and he never used to say much). when paul discovered that this is what they thought he decided to play along with it and put on a french accent...hahah so funny. but yeh so when he decided he wanted to put a french verse into it he asked a good freind who spoke it what rhymes with michelle. he ended up sending her a cheque for a sum of money for her contribution!!
